Let's take out the traditional architecture for the

So the idea of the decay-roll-up is that instead of sending
all the transactions to layer 1, you send all your
transactions to a layer 2 node.
And then layer 2 node will run some zero-no
proof algorithm and a generator proof.
So the proof will be verified on a smart contract layer 1.
And so, verifying the proof is a mathematical equivalent
to executing all the transactions.
So that's how you get this scalability, because for
example, if you only get 10 TPS, it can--
but each transaction is verifying some proof, which is
equivalent to executing 100 transactions.
Then you can scale your network massively.
So intuitively, the architecture of Scroll look like

So you need some sequencer, which is sequencing the
transaction after receiving that and the

And then you also need some relay to relay message between
layer 1 and layer 2.
For example, there are some deposits from layer 1 directly
through the bridge project.
And your relay need to relay this message from layer 1 to
layer 2.
And also, there are some deposits where sequencer need to
send this message to the relay.
And after sequencer sequencing the transaction, the
getting layer 2 blocks, it was sent to the prover and the
prover will run some algorithm, like the
run-up proof algorithm and the journey to proof.
And the relay will submit the proof as the rate data.
And a unique feature of Scroll is that we are not running
this prover in a centralized way.
But instead, we have a decentralized prover network
for generating the proof.
So in our architecture, we have a coordinator, which will
receive blocks from the sequencer and the
genetic execution trace.
It will dispatch the execution trace for different blocks

And the provers, we call them rollers in our network to

They run the KVM and the journey to proof.
And then we'll send back proof to the coordinator.

relay to the layer 1.

So after receiving this execution trace from the

So what is the KVM?
So the KVM is composed of several circuits.
So the circuit means--
so one circuit can verify certain functionalities for
certain parts.
For example, the KVM circuit can verify that your EVM state
machine moves correctly from push to pop and to the next
upcode you are executing.
And then run circuit is useful to prove that your read and
write for this virtual machine is consistent.
For example, you previously write to some place and then
you read.
So this run circuit can prove that those are consistent.
And there is also a storing circuit, which means when you
are updating the storage, you are doing things correctly.
And there are some other circuits to prove some other
functionalities for EVM, including ECD as a circuit for
signature and some bytecode circuits and some catch-act

And you need a circuit input builder in between to

And then, like, so intuitively, the KVM should have

Because it needs to have a proof for an EVM circuit, a

But all the proofs need to be verified only when efficient.
So what we do here is that we build another aggregation

So this aggregation circuit is used for proving that the
